content: <@!682078300234973185> Almost forgot. You mentioned the textbooks that you'd recommend using for a better notation in the witness specs. Which textbooks are these?

author: pauld.9606
content: I said that I want to copy textbook proof techniques -- this is to make it easy for people to check.

author: pauld.9606
content:
For unique readability, I am familiar with Ebbinghaus, Mathematical Logic, theorem 4.4, but I may also try Enderton, A Mathematical Introduction to Logic, section 1.3.1, 1.4.2, or 2.3.

For soundness of execution, I am looking at two popular texts, Harper, Practical Foundations for Programming Languages, chapter 6, and Pierce, Types and Programming Languages, chapter 8.3.

author: pauld.9606
content: For syntax, I think that we should use the most popular notation, [Backusâ€“Naur form](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backus%E2%80%93Naur_form), or an extension of it.

author: pauld.9606
content: For execution semantics, we are using small-step rewrite rules, this falls under [operational semantics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operational_semantics).

author: pauld.9606
content: I think that the syntax is the most important. The semantics may only be needed for the proof in an appendix, since most people won't actually use these semantics.

author: pauld.9606
content: Upon request, I can try to rewrite the spec in my own notation, based on Igor's current spec draft, trying to honor your format. Maybe this can help us iterate and move your draft to completion faster.
